abstract.p: Francis J Lodato letter on Sept 10 article on how Roman Catholic priests of 1960's fear replacement by generation that does not seem to share their values; says today's aspirants to priesthood show tremendous spirit of generosity

block.p: After working for 25 years in the seminary system, I see no need for pessimism about those who will replace the priests of the 1960's (front page, Sept. 10). Today's aspirants to the priesthood show a tremendous spirit of generosity, as seen in their weekly visits to homeless shelters, soup kitchens and facilities for the emotionally ill, elderly and infirm.

After working for 25 years in the seminary system, I see no need for pessimism about those who will replace the priests of the 1960's (front page, Sept. 10). Today's aspirants to the priesthood show a tremendous spirit of generosity, as seen in their weekly visits to homeless shelters, soup kitchens and facilities for the emotionally ill, elderly and infirm.

Every age has different needs, and so it is with the church. The emphasis on the sacredness of liturgy may help people appreciate the meaning of liturgical functions. It may also make the church not merely a place to congregate, but a place of worship.
FRANCIS J. LODATO Newtown, Conn., Sept. 11, 2000
The writer is consulting psychologist, Cathedral Seminary Residence of the Immaculate Conception.
